s.text: Today, Rubell is dead of AIDS, and Schrager owns the half-dozen most chic hotels in the United States.
It's hard to convey how much more interesting New York was in the late '70s than it is now.
It's hard to convey how much more interesting New York was in the late '70s than it is now.
One reason, I think, was a giddy feeling in the late '70s that the End was Nigh, so everything was permitted and there was no reason to compete.
It's hard to convey how much more interesting New York was in the late '70s than it is now.
It's hard to convey how much more interesting New York was in the late '70s than it is now.
John Sparrow, the late warden of All Souls College, put it nicely: "My impression is that in New York anything might happen at any moment.
It's hard to convey how much more interesting New York was in the late '70s than it is now.

The next thing I knew I was in a private room upstairs at the 21 Club having dinner with the lot of them.

And so the great party went jollily on, night after night, presided over by owner Steve Rubell, irrepressible though always zonked on 'ludes (co-owner Ian Schrager, the son of a Meyer Lansky lieutenant, was all but invisible).
